storm.asynchbase.bolt.mapper

Class AsyncHBaseFieldMapper

  • java.lang.Object
    • storm.asynchbase.bolt.mapper.AsyncHBaseFieldMapper
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, IAsyncHBaseFieldMapper

    public class AsyncHBaseFieldMapper
extends java.lang.Object
implements IAsyncHBaseFieldMapper

    This class configure an HBase RPC
    It maps tuple fields to part of the request and sets options

      void updateMapping()
      This has to be called before running the query
      Typically by the prepare method -- To get the right constructor to call to execute the rpc.
      If not you'll get a InvalidMapperException.
      If you change the mapping you have to call this method again.

      • updateMapping

        public void updateMapping()
        This has to be called before running the query
        Typically by the prepare method -- To get the right constructor to call to execute the rpc.
        If not you'll get a InvalidMapperException.
        If you change the mapping you have to call this method again.

      • setDurable

        public AsyncHBaseFieldMapper setDurable(boolean durable)

        Some methods or RPC types take a durable argument. When an edit requests to be durable, the success of the RPC guarantees that the edit is safely and durably stored by HBase and won't be lost. In case of server failures, the edit won't be lost although it may become momentarily unavailable. Setting the durable argument to false makes the operation complete faster (and puts a lot less strain on HBase), but removes this durability guarantee. In case of a server failure, the edit may (or may not) be lost forever. When in doubt, leave it to true (default). Setting it to false is useful in cases where data-loss is acceptable, e.g. during batch imports (where you can re-run the whole import in case of a failure), or when you intend to do statistical analysis on the data Bear in mind that this durability guarantee holds only once the RPC has completed successfully. Any edit temporarily buffered on the client side or in-flight will be lost if the client itself crashes. You can control how much buffering is done by the client by settings the client flushInterval. and you can force-flush the buffered edits by calling flush(). When you're done using HBase, you must not just give up your reference to your HBaseClient, you must shut it down gracefully by calling shutdown(). If you fail to do this, then all edits still buffered by the client will be lost.

        Parameters:
        durable - The durability setting of this edit.
        Returns:
        This so you can do method chaining.

      • setBufferable

        public AsyncHBaseFieldMapper setBufferable(boolean bufferable)
        Parameters:
        bufferable - Whether or not this RPC is can be buffered on the client side.
        Returns:
        This so you can do method chaining.
